habitat_description:
The California slender salamander occurs along the California coast and in the adjacent Inner Coast Ranges from north and east of Monterey Bay in extreme western Merced, Monterey, and San Benito counties; then northward into extreme southwestern Oregon in the south side of the Rogue River in Curry County (Leonard et al. 1993; Stebbins 2003). Populations also occur in the western foothills of the northern and central Sierra Nevada from Calaveras County north into Butte County (Hayes and Cliff 1982; Jockusch et al. 1998). The populations that occur in the Inner Coast Range extend as far north as Tehama County (Jennings 1982). Populations are also found north of California’s Central Valley in the Little Cow and Clipkapudi Creek drainages (Green et al. 2013).
Courtship behavior probably takes place underground (Houck 1977). The eggs are deposited beneath rocks, logs, and other objects, but likely underground also (Myers 1930; Lannoo 2005). It has been reported that juveniles may be more active than adults during conditions that are sub-optimal (Maiorana 1976). Adults are restricted to low elevation, coastal redwood forest (Bury 1983; Welsh and Lind 1988). But, in southwestern Oregon, this species is associated with humid coastal mixed evergreen forests (Leonard et al. 1993). Populations in the south occur over a broader range of habitats that include moist coastal forest to oak woodlands; reports from the Sierra Nevada are mainly associated with pine-oak woodland and foothills chaparral (Block and Morrison 1998), but populations do extend into the bottom of the Central Valley along riparian corridors (Hayes and Cliff 1982).
